questions.text: A patient suffered a blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago. He now complains of blurred vision. On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iridodialysis

 

Explanation:


 Iridodialysis is a specific type of traumatic eye injury characterized by:

 

  • Separation of the iris from its root (ciliary body attachment)
  • Typically caused by blunt trauma
  • Results in a D-shaped pupil
  • Occurs due to direct mechanical force disrupting the iris attachment

 

Other potential traumatic eye findings include:

 

  • Sphincter tear
  • Hyphema (blood in anterior chamber)
  • Traumatic cataract
  • Vossius ring (iron deposition on anterior lens capsule)

 

 

  • Retinal or zonular dialysis

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Vossius ring: Incorrect. While a Vossius ring is a traumatic finding (pigment deposition on anterior lens capsule), it does not explain the D-shaped pupil or significant structural change described in the question.

 

 

Option C. Cycloiriditis: Incorrect. This refers to inflammation of the ciliary body and iris, which is not specifically associated with blunt trauma or a D-shaped pupil.

 

Option D. Ankyloblepharon: Incorrect. This is an adhesion of the upper and lower eyelids, which is not related to the described traumatic finding or D-shaped pupil.



 

Educational Objective:


Iridodialysis is a specific traumatic eye injury characterized by separation of the iris from its root, typically resulting from blunt force trauma and presenting with a distinctive D-shaped pupil.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old patient presented with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was performed, and the reports are as follows: (FMGE JULY 2024)

 

  • Opening pressure – elevated
  • Appearance – cloudy
  • Cell count – 80 (70% PMNs)
  • Sugar – 35 mg/dL
  • Protein – 200 mg/dL

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Bacterial Meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of meningitis: fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis from the lumbar puncture provides several key clues:

 

  • Elevated opening pressure, which is common in bacterial meningitis.
  • Cloudy appearance of the CSF, indicating a high number of cells or increased protein.
  • Cell count of 80 with 70% polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs), which is highly indicative of bacterial infection as it typically shows a neutrophilic predominance.
  • Low glucose level (35 mg/dL) and elevated protein level (200 mg/dL), which are consistent with bacterial meningitis due to the consumption of glucose by bacteria and increased protein from the inflammatory process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Viral Meningitis: Viral meningitis usually presents with a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose levels. This does not match the neutrophil predominance and low glucose levels seen in this case.

 

Option C. TB Meningitis: TB meningitis often shows a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, significantly elevated protein levels, and moderately low glucose levels. While the glucose and protein levels could fit, the neutrophil predominance makes TB meningitis less likely.

 

Option D. Fungal Meningitis: Fungal meningitis typically presents with a mixed or lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, elevated protein, and low glucose. Neutrophilic predominance is not characteristic of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute bacterial meningitis is characterized by elevated opening pressure, cloudy CSF, a high cell count with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and elevated protein levels in the CSF.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

 

Gastric lavage, also known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, involves the removal of the stomach's contents via a tube. It is contraindicated in certain situations due to the risks involved.

 

Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine is a convulsive poison. Performing gastric lavage on a patient with strychnine poisoning is highly dangerous because it can induce further convulsions and seizures. Gastric lavage acts as a stimulus, which can exacerbate the convulsions, leading to a higher risk of complications including aspiration of stomach contents into the lungs.

 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

 

  • Corrosive substances (an absolute C/I): Risk of gastric perforation except for carbolic acid, which hardens the stomach wall.
  • Convulsive patients: Risk of aspiration.
  • Comatose patients: Also at risk of aspiration unless the airway is protected.
  • Kerosene & other volatile poison, including hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons are volatile and can cause chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Oesophageal Varices

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ingestion of paraldehyde: Paraldehyde ingestion does not have the same risk of inducing convulsions or seizures. Gastric lavage can be considered in some cases, but it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ingestion of hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons, such as kerosene, are volatile and pose a high risk of aspiration leading to chemical pneumonitis. While this is also a contraindication, the most critical contraindication here is strychnine poisoning due to the additional risk of inducing seizures.

 

Option D. Iron tablet ingestion: Iron tablets do not pose a high risk of convulsions or severe aspiration. Gastric lavage can be used in cases of iron tablet ingestion if done early and under proper medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bladder exstrophy

 

The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

 

Ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. Clinical features of this condition include separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis, epispadias, and genital defects such as bifid clitoris in females and broad and short penis with bilateral inguinal hernia in males.

 

Management of bladder exstrophy involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. The first step is closure of the abdominal and bladder wall within the first year of life. This procedure may require an iliac osteotomy to relieve tension on the bladder and facilitate wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects may be performed. Alternatively, urinary diversion can be carried out by creating ureterosigmoid anastomosis, an ileal or colonic conduit, or continent urinary diversion.

 

Long-term complications of bladder exstrophy include stricture at the site of the anastomosis leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and infection, hyperchloremic acidosis, and an increased (20-fold) risk of tumor formation such as adenoma and adenocarcinoma at the site of a ureteroscopic anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: The abdominal contents are out and are covered in a sac. It is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect. It occurs due to the failure of the physiological umbilical hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels and chromosomal abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: It is a congenital anomaly that occurs during fetal development. The vitelline duct is a structure that connects the developing embryo to the yolk sac. In normal development, the vitelline duct is supposed to disappear by the time the fetus is born. However, in some cases, the duct persists and can lead to various complications.

 

Option D. gastrochisis: in this condition, the abdominal contents are out and are NOT covered in a sac.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. The management involves staged surgical reconstruction, and complications include strictures, hyperchloremic acidosis, and increased risk of tumors.

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is used for which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genome editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is a revolutionary technology used primarily for genome editing. The system allows scientists to alter DNA sequences and modify gene function. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) component is a segment of DNA containing short repetitions of base sequences, and the Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) is an enzyme that can cut DNA at specific locations guided by RNA. This technology enables the precise removal, addition, or alteration of sections of the DNA sequence, which makes it incredibly powerful for correcting genetic defects, studying gene function, and even treating genetic diseases.

 

While CRISPR-Cas9 has potential applications in diagnostics, such as detecting viral infections, its primary and most well-known application is in genome editing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DNA analysis: Although CRISPR technology can be used in some diagnostic contexts, DNA analysis typically refers to techniques like PCR, sequencing, and electrophoresis. CRISPR-Cas9's main function is not analysis but editing.

 

Option C. Determination of chromosomal defects: Chromosomal defects are usually determined through methods like karyotyping or FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization). CRISPR-Cas9 is not used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities but for editing specific gene sequences.

 

Option D. Radiological diagnosis: Radiological diagnosis involves imaging techniques like X-rays, CT scans, and MRIs. CRISPR-Cas9 is unrelated to these imaging methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is a cutting-edge technology used primarily for genome editing, allowing for the precise modification of DNA sequences, which holds great promise for treating genetic disorders and advancing genetic research.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of School Health under Ayushman Bharat Program? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Monthly IFA supplementations

 

The Ayushman Bharat Program includes a comprehensive school health component aimed at improving the health and hygiene of school children. The key components include:

 

  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS): This involves the distribution of iron and folic acid supplements on a weekly basis to prevent anemia among school children. Monthly supplementation is not part of this program; hence, "Monthly IFA supplementations" is the incorrect option.
  • Sanitary Napkins Distribution: Under the menstrual hygiene scheme, sanitary napkins branded as "Freedays" are distributed to adolescent girls to promote menstrual hygiene.
  • Albendazole for Deworming: Deworming through albendazole is conducted to reduce the prevalence of intestinal worm infestations among school-aged children.
  • Health Check-ups: Regular health screenings are conducted to assess the physical and mental fitness of students, ensuring early identification and management of health issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat School Health Program includes weekly IFA supplementation, not monthly, along with other health initiatives like menstrual hygiene, deworming, screening health check-ups, physical & mental fitness, Research and Vaccination

questions.text: The process of converting unconjugated to conjugated foreign substance is known as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucuronidation

 

The process of converting an unconjugated foreign substance to a conjugated form is a part of the body's detoxification mechanism, primarily occurring in the liver. This process is essential for making the substance more water-soluble, which facilitates its excretion from the body. Glucuronidation is a phase II metabolic reaction where a glucuronic acid molecule is attached to the substance, making it more hydrophilic and easier to eliminate via bile or urine.

 

Phase I reactions, such as oxidation (including hydroxylation), are generally the first step in detoxification and involve the modification of the foreign substance to make it more reactive. Phase II reactions, such as glucuronidation, follow to further modify the substance for excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycation: Glycation refers to the non-enzymatic attachment of sugars to proteins or lipids, often resulting in advanced glycation end products (AGEs). This is unrelated to the conjugation process in detoxification.

 

Option C. Glycosylation: Glycosylation is the enzymatic process where sugars are attached to proteins or lipids, typically involved in cellular functions and protein folding, not in detoxification.

 

Option D. Oxidation: Oxidation is a phase I reaction in detoxification, where substances are modified by adding oxygen or removing hydrogen. However, it is not the process of converting unconjugated substances to conjugated ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucuronidation is a phase II metabolic process where an unconjugated foreign substance is converted into a conjugated form, making it more water-soluble and easier for the body to excrete.

 

Note –

 

Foreign substance are detoxified in liver by -

 

Phase I – Oxidation reaction – Hydroxylation

 

Phase II – Conjugation – Glucouronide, Glutathione and Sulfation

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liposomal Amphotericin B plus 5-FC

 

Explanation:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine (5-FC). This combination is used during the initial induction phase of treatment. 

 

Liposomal amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death. 

 

 

5-flucytosine is an antimetabolite that inhibits DNA and protein synthesis in fungal cells. The combination therapy provides synergistic effects against Cryptococcus, especially in the central nervous system infections like meningitis.

 

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis typically follows a three-phase approach:

 

  1. Induction phase - liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine
  2. Consolidation phase - fluconazole
  3. Maintenance phase- fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is used in the maintenance & Consolidation phase of cryptococcal meningitis treatment, not as the primary drug of choice for acute infection. It's less effective than amphotericin B for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option C. 5-Flucytosine: While 5-flucytosine is an important component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it is not used as monotherapy. It has limited efficacy when used alone and is primarily used in combination with amphotericin B to enhance fungicidal activity.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, interfering with ergosterol synthesis. It is primarily used for dermatophyte infections (tinea infections of skin, hair, and nails).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is the combination of liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for maintenance & Consolidation therapy.

questions.text: The micronutrient deficient in a patient with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cu (Copper)

 

Copper deficiency can present with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of the skin and hair. Copper is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes, including tyrosinase, which is involved in the conversion of tyrosine to melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. When copper is deficient, melanin production decreases, leading to hypopigmentation. Additionally, copper plays a role in iron metabolism and immune function, which explains the anemia and neutropenia observed in copper deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zn (Zinc): Zinc deficiency is characterized by delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, hypogonadism, and diarrhea. While zinc is important for various enzymatic functions, it does not specifically cause hypopigmentation or the combination of anemia and neutropenia seen with copper deficiency.

 

Option B. Se (Selenium): Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which primarily affects the heart and can lead to cardiomyopathy. Selenium plays a role in antioxidant protection but does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Fe (Iron): Iron deficiency primarily causes microcytic anemia, fatigue, and pallor. It does not lead to neutropenia or hypopigmentation of the skin and hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency is associated with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation due to its role in melanin synthesis and various other enzymatic processes.

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: A child had a fall at home and was treated with an elbow cast. After the removal of the cast, the child developed the deformity as shown. Which fracture most likely caused this deformity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

The image shows a child with a deformity known as cubitus varus, which is a complication of supracondylar humerus fractures. This deformity occurs when the distal part of the arm deviates medially, leading to a "gunstock" appearance of the arm. Cubitus varus is a known consequence of a malunited supracondylar humerus fracture, where the carrying angle of the elbow is reduced.

 

Supracondylar fractures are common in children, especially after a fall on an outstretched hand, and improper alignment during healing can lead to this deformity. The deformity is mostly a cosmetic issue but is directly associated with this type of fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial head fracture: Radial head fractures typically present with pain during rotation of the forearm and do not commonly cause cubitus varus or valgus deformities. The main issue with radial head fractures is decreased range of motion, particularly pronation and supination, rather than a visible deformity like in this case.

 

Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture: A lateral condyle fracture can lead to cubitus valgus, where the distal part of the arm deviates laterally, increasing the carrying angle. This is the opposite deformity to cubitus varus, which we see here. Non-union of lateral condyle fractures is the common cause of cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus.

 

Option C. Mid-shaft humerus fracture: A mid-shaft humerus fracture does not typically result in deformities like cubitus varus. While this fracture can result in functional issues, especially related to nerve injury (such as radial nerve palsy), it does not lead to elbow deformities unless complicated by additional elbow injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus varus, a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OAE

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening. OAE testing is a simple, quick, and non-invasive method that measures sounds (emissions) produced by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to an auditory stimulus. This test is highly effective for detecting hearing loss in newborns and can be performed shortly after birth. If the OAE test results are normal, no further testing is needed. However, if the OAE test is abnormal, further evaluation with Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is recommended after three months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BERA: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used if OAE results are abnormal. It is more comprehensive but not used as the initial screening test due to its complexity and requirement for specialized equipment.

 

Option C. PTA: Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) is not suitable for newborns as it requires behavioral responses to sound, which cannot be reliably obtained from newborns.

 

Option D. Impedance: Impedance audiometry measures the function of the middle ear but is not used for initial newborn hearing screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a sampling method where the total population is divided into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, and then random samples are taken from each stratum. In this question, the total population consists of three different groups: plants, animals, and humans, each forming a distinct stratum. After forming these strata, random sampling is conducted within each group to select samples, ensuring representation from all subgroups.

 

This approach ensures that the study includes balanced and proportional representation of each group, reflecting the actual composition of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Simple random sampling involves selecting individuals purely by chance from the entire population without dividing it into subgroups. In this scenario, samples are taken from specific groups rather than randomly from the entire population.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting samples from a population at regular intervals (e.g., every nth member). This technique is not used here as the sampling is done within defined groups, not systematically across the whole population.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters (often geographically or by natural grouping), and entire clusters are randomly selected for study. In this question, the groups (plants, animals, humans) are not clusters but strata, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups and then conducting random sampling within each subgroup.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh
Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers
No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area
Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female having a new sexual partner / boyfriend presented with painful ulcer on the vulva and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation of a painful genital ulcer along with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy strongly suggests chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • Causative agent: Haemophilus ducreyi (Gram-negative coccobacillus).
  • Incubation period: 2-5 days after sexual exposure.
  • Genital ulcer characteristics:
    • Multiple, painful ulcers.

 

 

  • Irregular, soft edges (hence the term soft chancre).
  • Necrotic, yellow-gray base with purulent discharge.
  • Bleeds on touch.

 

Inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo):

 

  • Painful, unilateral or bilateral lymph nodes.

 

 

  • May progress to suppuration and rupture.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Clinical diagnosis is common.
  • Gram stain of ulcer exudate: "School of fish" or "railroad track" appearance.
  • Culture on Mueller-Hinton agar (low sensitivity).

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line therapy: Azithromycin (1 g single dose) or Ceftriaxone (250 mg IM single dose).
  • Alternative therapy: Erythromycin or Ciprofloxacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neisseria (Gonorrhea):

 

  • Causes purulent urethral or cervical discharge.
  • Does not cause genital ulcers.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Presents with a painless, beefy-red ulcer that bleeds easily.
  • No lymphadenopathy (pseudo-bubo may be seen).

 

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

 

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serovars).
  • Begins with a small, painless ulcer that heals spontaneously.
  • Followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo) associated with groove sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presenting as painful genital ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is treated with Azithromycin or Ceftriaxone.

questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

 

The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate or physis, is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones in children and adolescents. It consists primarily of cartilage, made up of type II collagen, which progressively ossifies to contribute to the bone's lengthening. This growth plate remains active until it closes after puberty, marking the end of the bone's longitudinal growth. Any fracture affecting this area, such as a Salter-Harris fracture, can disrupt this growth process, potentially leading to growth disturbances or deformities.

 

The other regions of the bone (diaphysis, epiphysis, and metaphysis) are involved in different processes, but they do not directly influence the longitudinal growth as the epiphyseal plate does.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphysis: This is the shaft of the long bone, primarily involved in providing structural support and is not directly responsible for longitudinal growth. Fractures in the diaphysis do not affect the bone's length.

 

Option B. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone, which forms the joint surface. It plays a role in articulating with adjacent bones and, while important for bone structure, it does not contribute directly to longitudinal growth.

 

Option D. Metaphysis: This is the wide portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and the diaphysis. It is highly vascular and is a common site for bone tumors and infections but is not responsible for the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.

questions.text: Which of the following pathology is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The image provided shows a typical sign of free air under the right dome of the diaphragm. This finding is highly indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. When there is a perforation in any part of the gastrointestinal tract, air can escape into the peritoneal cavity. This air then rises to the highest point in the abdomen when the patient is in an upright position, which is under the diaphragm, and is visible on an upright chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subacute intestinal obstruction: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it would typically show dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus would also not present with free air under the diaphragm. It usually shows diffusely dilated bowel loops without a transition point on imaging studies.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: A pleural effusion involves fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity and would not present with air under the diaphragm. It typically shows fluid in the pleural space on a chest X-ray, often blurring the costophrenic angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. This is a critical sign that should prompt immediate medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: The chronic alcoholic patient had a history of strenuous exercise but forgot to take his meal, later had alcohol in a party, and presented with hypoglycemia. Which of the following processes is inhibited by alcohol? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gluconeogenesis

 

Alcohol metabolism involves the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetic acid. Both steps generate NADH through the actions of alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, respectively. The excessive production of NADH in the liver causes a shift in the metabolic equilibrium.

 

Increased levels of NADH favor the conversion of pyruvate to lactate (lactic acidosis) and oxaloacetate to malate. Since pyruvate and oxaloacetate are key substrates for gluconeogenesis (the process of generating glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), their depletion inhibits gluconeogenesis. This metabolic inhibition leads to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted, as in the case of the patient who had undergone strenuous exercise and had not eaten.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogenolysis: This process, which involves the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, is not directly inhibited by alcohol. However, once glycogen stores are depleted, the body relies on gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels, which is impaired by alcohol.

 

Option B. HMP shunt: The Hexose Monophosphate shunt (also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway) is involved in generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate but is not directly affected by alcohol metabolism.

 

Option D. Ketone bodies synthesis: While chronic alcohol consumption can lead to ketoacidosis, the synthesis of ketone bodies is not inhibited by alcohol. Instead, alcohol can lead to a buildup of acetyl-CoA, which can actually promote ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH, which inhibits gluconeogenesis by depleting pyruvate and oxaloacetate, leading to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Signs of Cocaine intoxication:

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Myocardial ischemia: Cocaine can induce myocardial ischemia due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties on coronary arteries.

 

Option C. Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia is a common symptom of cocaine intoxication due to increased metabolic activity and muscle activity.

 

Option D. Agitation: Agitation is a well-known effect of cocaine's stimulant properties on the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine poisoning typically causes increased heart rate (tachycardia) rather than bradycardia, along with other symptoms like myocardial ischemia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular tumor found in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for JNA is Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT is preferred because it effectively delineates the bony margins and the extent of the tumor, including any bone erosion. The contrast enhancement helps in identifying the vascular nature of the tumor, which is crucial in differentiating JNA from other masses in the nasal cavity, such as adenoids or carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is helpful for assessing orbital and cranial extensions of the tumor but is not the primary choice for initial diagnosis. It does not provide as clear an image of the bony structures as CECT does.

 

Option C. DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy): While DNE can visualize a mass in the nasal cavity, it cannot determine the type of mass or its vascular nature. It is less informative than imaging studies in the diagnosis of JNA.

 

Option D. Biopsy: Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected JNA due to the high risk of severe bleeding given the vascular nature of the tumor. Attempting a biopsy can lead to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:


The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: pH -7.50; Pco2 –48mmHg; HCO3-30meq/l? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Explanation: 

 

  • pH is 7.5 (elevated above normal 7.35-7.45) indicating alkalosis
  • PCO2 is 48 mmHg (elevated above normal 35-45 mmHg) indicating respiratory compensation
  • HCO3 is 30 meq/L (elevated above normal 22-26 meq/L)

 

This represents a primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. The elevated HCO3 is the primary disorder causing the alkalosis. The elevated PCO2 represents appropriate respiratory compensation (hypoventilation) attempting to normalize the pH by retaining CO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis presents with low pH (<7.35) and low HCO3, which is opposite to the values given.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis:Incorrect because respiratory alkalosis presents with high pH but low PCO2, whereas here PCO2 is elevated.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis:Incorrect because respiratory acidosis presents with low pH and high PCO2. While PCO2 is high here, the pH is alkalotic rather than acidotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas interpretation, metabolic alkalosis is characterized by:

 

  • Elevated pH (>7.45)
  • Elevated HCO3 (>26 meq/L)
  • Compensatory elevation in PCO2 through hypoventilation

questions.text: A patient presents with diminution of vision. He has a H/o ATT intake. The causative drug is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the most likely causative drug for vision problems in patients taking anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). It can cause toxic optic neuropathy, leading to diminution of vision. This side effect is dose-dependent and usually reversible if detected early and the drug is discontinued. Ethambutol primarily affects the optic nerve, causing decreased visual acuity, altered color perception (especially red-green color blindness), and central scotomas.

 

Toxic Amblyopia caused by drugs:

 

  • Ethambutol
  • Tobacco
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Quinine
  • Ethyl Alcohol
  • Methyl Alcohol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazinamide: This drug is not commonly used in ATT and is not typically associated with vision problems.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: While an important component of ATT, rifampicin is not primarily associated with vision changes. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: Although isoniazid can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with optic neuropathy or vision changes. Its main neurological side effect is peripheral neuropathy, which can be prevented by administering pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathy, causing diminution of vision in patients on ATT. Regular ophthalmic monitoring is crucial for patients on ethambutol to detect early signs of toxicity

questions.text: Case fatality rate of the disease rabies is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100%.

 

Rabies is one of the deadliest infectious diseases, with a case fatality rate approaching 100%. This means that once clinical symptoms of rabies appear, the disease is almost always fatal, making it the highest fatality rate for any known disease.

 

The case fatality rate is calculated by dividing the number of deaths due to a disease by the number of diagnosed cases of that disease and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.

 

The reason rabies has such a high case fatality rate is due to the virus's effects on the central nervous system, leading to acute encephalitis (inflammation of the brain). Once symptoms develop, there is no effective treatment, and death usually occurs within days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease.
  • CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%.
  • Measles has a CFR of 3%.
  • Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.

choices.text: They act on extracellular receptors only
It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor
Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding the secondary messenger? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mediate intracellular hormone response

 

Secondary messengers are molecules that relay signals received at receptors on the cell surface to target molecules inside the cell. When a hormone binds to its extracellular receptor, it triggers the production of secondary messengers inside the cell. These secondary messengers, such as cyclic AMP (cAMP), inositol triphosphate (IP3), and calcium ions, then activate protein kinases and other enzymes, leading to an intracellular response. This process is crucial for the amplification of the signal and the initiation of specific cellular activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They act on extracellular receptors only: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers do not act on receptors; they are produced inside the cell after the hormone binds to an extracellular receptor.

 

Option B. It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers activate protein kinases that may eventually affect nuclear processes, but the secondary messengers themselves do not directly transmit impulses to nuclear receptors.

 

Option D. Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers act within the cell and do not interact with extracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary messengers mediate intracellular hormone responses by transmitting signals from cell surface receptors to target molecules within the cell, leading to a specific cellular response.

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh phenotype, is one of the rarest blood groups in the world. It was discovered in 1952 by Dr Y.M. Bhende.

 

Individuals with this blood group lack the H antigen, which is a precursor to the A and B antigens found on the red blood cells of most individuals. The absence of the H antigen means that even blood type O, which normally has the H antigen, is not compatible with individuals who have the Bombay phenotype.

 

People with the Bombay blood group produce anti-H antibodies in addition to anti-A and anti-B antibodies. This means that they cannot receive blood from any of the common blood types (A, B, AB, or O), as all of these contain the H antigen and would lead to a severe transfusion reaction.

 

The only blood that can be safely transfused into a person with the Bombay blood group is blood from another Bombay blood group donor, which is denoted as Oh.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB: Individuals with blood group AB have both A and B antigens. This blood group would not be compatible with a Bombay blood group recipient, as it would cause a severe transfusion reaction due to the presence of H antigen.

 

Option B. O positive: Blood group O positive still has the H antigen, even though it lacks A and B antigens. Transfusing O positive blood into a Bombay blood group individual would also lead to a transfusion reaction.

 

Option D. O negative: Like O positive, O negative blood has the H antigen and would not be suitable for a Bombay blood group recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

 

Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Correct. Intermittent claudication most commonly affects the calf muscles because the disease often affects the arteries supplying the lower limbs, usually the superficial femoral artery (70% of cases). Patients describe it as a cramping or aching sensation that occurs with walking or exertion and is relieved with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Felt at rest: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest. It occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles during exertion.

 

Option C. Day to day distance is variable: Incorrect. While the severity of peripheral artery disease can change over time (especially without treatment), typically, the distance a person can walk before symptoms begin is fairly consistent, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Relieved after getting out of bed: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication pain is typically relieved after a few minutes of rest and doesn't specifically correlate with getting out of bed. The pain usually occurs during physical activities, such as walking, and subsides with rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

questions.text: A patient had a cataract surgery 3 years back, now complains of decrease in vision and presented with the following slit lamp image. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior capsular opacification


Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is the most common complication occurring after cataract surgery. It is often referred to as an "after cataract" or "secondary cataract." PCO develops when lens epithelial cells remaining after surgery migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule, which eventually leads to clouding.

 

The clinical presentation typically involves gradual vision loss without pain, as seen in this case. The slit lamp image provided shows an intraocular lens in place with opacification of the posterior capsule, which confirms the diagnosis of PCO.

 

The standard treatment for PCO is Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy, a simple and effective procedure to restore vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy: This condition occurs due to endothelial cell loss following cataract surgery, leading to corneal decompensation and formation of painful bullae on the corneal surface. It presents with pain and redness in the eye, which is not observed in this patient.

 

 

Option C. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophy is a genetic disorder that usually presents bilaterally and is unrelated to cataract surgery. It does not cause symptoms similar to those seen in this case and would not present specifically in one eye following cataract surgery.

 

 

Option D. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: This type of cataract develops in the back of the lens before surgery and is not seen after cataract surgery. Once removed during cataract surgery, posterior subcapsular cataracts do not recur.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication after cataract surgery, presenting with gradual vision loss without pain. It is treated with ND laser capsulotomy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

 

The pedigree chart shown in Image 2 demonstrates a clear pattern of mitochondrial inheritance. Key characteristics of this inheritance pattern are:

 

  1. Maternal transmission: The disease is passed down exclusively from affected mothers to all their children (both sons and daughters).
  2. No paternal transmission: Affected fathers do not pass the condition to any of their offspring.
  3. All offspring of an affected mother are affected: This is because all mitochondria in a zygote come from the egg cell.

 

In the pedigree, we can see that in each generation, affected mothers (filled circles) transmit the condition to all their children, while affected fathers (filled squares) do not pass it on to any of their children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal Dominant: Incorrect. This pattern would show affected individuals in every generation, but both males and females would be able to transmit the condition to their offspring.

 

Option B. Autosomal Recessive: Incorrect. This pattern typically shows skip generations and requires both parents to be carriers or affected for the offspring to be affected.

 

Option C. X linked recessive: Incorrect. This pattern would show predominantly affected males, with females as carriers, and no male-to-male transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission of a trait to all offspring, with no paternal transmission, due to the exclusive inheritance of mitochondria from the mother's egg cell

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

choices.text: Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. But don’t tell the sex to the mother.
Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. Tell the sex to the mother.
Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, and gestational age. Don’t check for sex.

questions.text: A G5L4 woman has 4 daughters. She now comes for USG examination of her fetus and asks for sex determination. What will you do? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, and gestational age. Don’t check for sex.

 

According to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act in many countries, including India, determining and disclosing the sex of the fetus during ultrasound is illegal and strictly prohibited, regardless of the patient’s family history or number of children of a specific sex. The purpose of the ultrasound should be solely to assess the health of the fetus, including checking for congenital abnormalities and determining the gestational age.

 

Radiologists may, in practice, be aware of the fetal sex when checking for specific congenital abnormalities that are sex-linked; however, neither the act of checking for sex nor disclosing the sex to the parents is legally permissible. The correct approach, as per the law, is to conduct the ultrasound for medical indications only and not involve fetal sex determination.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. But don’t tell the sex to the mother: This option is incorrect as checking the sex is itself illegal under the PCPNDT Act, even if it is not disclosed to the parents.

 

Option B. Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. Tell the sex to the mother: This option is both legally and ethically wrong, as checking and disclosing fetal sex is prohibited by law.

 

Option D. Don’t Do the USG: This option is incorrect because conducting an ultrasound for assessing fetal health (such as checking for congenital abnormalities and gestational age) is appropriate and medically necessary, provided it does not include sex determination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The law prohibits both the determination and disclosure of fetal sex during ultrasound examinations. Ultrasound should be performed strictly for medical indications such as assessing fetal health, detecting congenital abnormalities, and determining gestational age, without involving sex determination.

questions.text: Which vitamin can be deficient in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly occurs in patients who have undergone a gastrectomy because the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor, are removed or significantly reduced. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot form the necessary complex to be absorbed, leading to deficiency. Conditions such as atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and autoimmune diseases that affect intrinsic factor can also result in similar deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is usually associated with malabsorption syndromes affecting fat absorption, not specifically with gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C absorption occurs primarily in the small intestine and is not directly affected by the absence of the stomach.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D absorption occurs in the small intestine and depends on fat absorption, which is generally not impacted by gastrectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach's parietal cells, which is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mannitol

 

The patient is experiencing Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during or after hemodialysis, especially in patients with initially very high urea levels undergoing dialysis for the first time. DDS is caused by a rapid decrease in urea levels in the blood, leading to a sudden change in osmolarity, which causes water to move into the cells, resulting in cerebral edema and neurological symptoms such as drowsiness and seizures.

 

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS): This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms due to cerebral edema caused by rapid changes in blood urea levels during dialysis.
  • Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic is used to treat cerebral edema by reducing intracranial pressure and drawing fluid out of the brain cells, thus decreasing cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bumetanide: This loop diuretic is used for fluid overload but not specifically indicated for treating cerebral edema in DDS.

 

Option B. Ethacrynic acid: Another loop diuretic, similar to bumetanide, and not used for DDS.

 

Option C. Nesiritide: A recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide used in acute heart failure, not for treating DDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

choices.text: Laser ablation can be used for treatment

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with dilated, tortuous veins in the leg. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laser ablation can be used for treatment

 

Explanation:

 

Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) is an effective minimally invasive treatment for varicose veins

 

  • EVLA works by using laser energy to cause thermal damage to vein wall
  • It has high success rate and faster recovery compared to traditional surgery
  • It is currently the treatment of choice for great saphenous vein varicosities
  • Done under local tumescent anesthesia as daycare procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clinical stage is C6: Incorrect as C6 indicates active venous ulcer. This patient only shows varicose veins which is C2 in CEAP classification (C2S if symptomatic, C2A if asymptomatic)

 

Option C. Sclerotherapy is the first-line treatment: Incorrect as sclerotherapy is primarily used for small reticular veins and telangiectasias, not for large varicose veins

 

Option D. Compression stockings are curative: Incorrect as compression stockings only provide symptomatic relief and don't cure varicose veins. They help manage symptoms but disease continues to progress

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) is an effective, first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. Compression stockings provide symptom relief but are not curative.

questions.text: Identify the congenital abnormality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open Neural Tube Defect

 

The image shows an open neural tube defect (ONTD) where there is complete non-closure of the neural tube during embryonic development. It specifically shows anterior neuropore defect characterized by:

 

  • Absent cranial vault
  • Exposed neural tissue
  • Exophthalmos (prominent eyes)
  • Chin resting on chest This represents a severe form of neural tube defect where both anterior and posterior neuropores have failed to close by day 28 of embryonic development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myelomeningocele: While this is also a neural tube defect, it specifically refers to protrusion of spinal cord and meninges through a defect in vertebral column. The image shows a more extensive defect.

 

Option B. Spina bifida occulta: This is a mild form where vertebral arches fail to fuse but spinal cord remains intact and covered by skin. The image shows exposed neural tissue.

 

 

Option C. Anencephaly: A failure of the cranial neuropore to close, leading to absence of the skull and most of the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Open Neural Tube Defects (ONTDs) result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during early development. They can manifest in various forms, including myelomeningocele and anencephaly, depending on the site of the defect.
