Adequate maternal folate supplementation is critical for reducing the risk of ONTDs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with low-grade fever and cough. Chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Miliary TB

 

The patient in this case presents with a low-grade fever and cough. The chest X-ray reveals multiple small nodules distributed throughout the bilateral lung fields, which is characteristic of miliary tuberculosis (TB). Miliary TB is a form of tuberculosis that occurs when a large number of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria spread through the bloodstream to multiple organs, including the lungs. This results in the appearance of numerous tiny nodules on the chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: While metastatic lung cancer can sometimes present with a similar pattern of multiple nodules on a chest X-ray, the presence of low-grade fever and the specific distribution of nodules are more indicative of miliary TB, especially in regions with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that typically form in pre-existing lung cavities, often resulting from previous tuberculosis infections. The chest X-ray appearance of aspergillomas is quite different from the diffuse nodules seen in miliary TB.

 

Option D. ARDS: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) presents with diffuse alveolar damage and is characterized by rapid onset of widespread inflammation in the lungs. The chest X-ray findings for ARDS usually show diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than the small, discrete nodules seen in miliary TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis should be suspected in patients with low-grade fever, cough, and a chest X-ray showing multiple small nodules throughout the lung fields, especially in regions with high tuberculosis prevalence.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text: Monkeypox detection is best done by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Real-Time PCR

 

Monkeypox virus is a double-stranded DNA virus, and the most effective method for detecting DNA viruses is through Real-Time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). Real-Time PCR allows for the rapid and precise amplification of DNA, making it a highly sensitive and specific tool for detecting the presence of the Monkeypox virus in a sample. This method can detect even small amounts of viral DNA, making it the best option for early and accurate diagnosis.

 

In cases where the pathogen is an RNA virus, the detection process typically starts with Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), where RNA is first converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) before amplification. However, since Monkeypox is a DNA virus, Real-Time PCR is directly applicable without the need for this additional step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is useful for detecting antibodies or antigens related to an infection, it is not the most direct or sensitive method for detecting the DNA of the Monkeypox virus.

 

Option B. Hemagglutination: Hemagglutination is a method used to detect viruses that cause red blood cells to clump together. This method is not applicable for detecting Monkeypox virus, which does not cause hemagglutination.

 

Option C. Western Blot: Western Blot is used primarily to detect specific proteins in a sample and is more commonly associated with confirming the presence of antibodies, such as in HIV testing. It is not the best method for detecting a DNA virus like Monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Real-Time PCR is the most effective and reliable method for detecting Monkeypox virus, a double-stranded DNA virus, due to its sensitivity and specificity

questions.text: What is the indication of this procedure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratoconus

 

The given image shows the placement of Intacs, which is done for keratoconus.

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea.
  • Pathognomonic features include central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea.
  • Defective vision, progressive myopia, and irregular astigmatism are common clinical features.
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present.
  • Clinical signs: 
    1. Scissor reflex (yawning reflex) on retinoscopy is the earliest sign.
    2. Oil droplet reflex is seen with distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
    3. Fleischer’s ring (Epithelial iron deposits) and Vogt lines (Oblique stromal striae) (Image given below) are seen on slit lamp examination.
      Note: Kayser –fleischer ring is due to deposition of the copper and is seen in Wilson disease and chalcosis.
    4. Rizzuti's sign, a bright reflection from the nasal area of the limbus when light is directed to the limbus temporal area.
    5. Munson’s sign (localized bulging of the lower lid on looking down) is positive in keratoconus. (Image given below)
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Vogt’s line:

 

Vogt’s triad

 

Occurs centrally in a patient with keratoconus

  • Vertical stromal/ Descemet’s membrane lines.
  • Stress lines due to stretching and thinning.
  • Disappear with globe pressure.

 

 

  • The earliest way to detect any curvature disease of the cornea including keratoconus is topography (mapping of the point-to-point thickness of the cornea).
  • The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry.
  • Treatment: Declining visual acuity may not be corrected by glasses due to irregular astigmatism.
    1. In early cases:
      • Contact lenses (rigid gas permeable)
      • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments (flatten the cornea)
    2. In later stages: Penetrating keratoplasty may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's limbal girdle: Vogt's limbal girdle is a benign, age-related condition characterized by white, chalky deposits at the limbus. It is not treated with Intacs.

 

Option C. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a condition characterized by a generalized thinning and globular protrusion of the entire cornea. It is not typically treated with Intacs.

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic, often progressive, eye disorders in which abnormal material accumulates in the cornea. Treatment varies and does not typically involve Intacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The placement of Intacs is an indicated treatment for keratoconus, a condition characterized by the thinning and protrusion of the cornea leading to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism.
